title: Project Attento
text:
This is the website for project ATTENTO. The Attento project explores the application of different attentional foci in people with functional motor disorders (FMD).
On this website you can find information on:

Project updates
Functional motor disorders (Defintions. categories, associated problems, assessment and treatment)
How can different stakeholders use different attentional foci to increase skill acquisition in people with FMD.

How to design statements with different attentional foci
Example exercises

title: Functional Motor disorders
text:
This is the Wikipedia definition of functional neurologic disorders
Link Wikipedia
Functional neurologic disorder or functional neurological disorder (FND) is a condition in which patients experience neurological symptoms such as weakness, movement disorders, sensory symptoms, and blackouts. As a functional disorder, there is by definition no known disease process affecting the structure of the body, yet the person experiences symptoms relating to their body function. Symptoms of functional neurological disorders are clinically recognisable, but are not categorically associated with a definable organic disease.

title: Treatment of Functional Motor disorders
text:
In 2015 an expert group publised the following physiotheray treatment recommendations for people with FMD (Nielsen et al. 2015)
Here are some core recommendations:








Relationship
Treatment
Assistive devices




Build trust
Limit “hands on treatment”
Avoid use of splints


Create expectation of improvement
Foster independence
Avoid immobilisation of joints


Involve family
Use “goal directed” apporaches
Avoid adaptive equipment







References

Nielsen, Glenn, Jon Stone, Audrey Matthews, Melanie Brown, Chris Sparkes, Ross Farmer, Lindsay Masterton, Linsey Duncan, Alisa Winters, and Laura Daniell. 2015. “Physiotherapy for Functional Motor Disorders: A Consensus Recommendation.” Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery & Psychiatry 86 (10): 11131119.

title: Focus of attention
text:
Wulf et al. published in 1998 the first study exploring the effectiveness of an external focus of attention with an internal focus of attention. They reported that skill acquisition was better with an external focus of control (Wulf, HoB, and Prinz 1998).
